bibl.title: Notes from Liberian Legation In U.S. to Department of State, 1862-1898 T807

body.div1:
LIBERIA
From our Liverpool Correspondent
The sad murder of two French travelers in the territories of the Liberian Republic has provided the French Government with a powerful and singularly opportune weapon in the furtherance with a powerful and encroachment upon that Negro State. The German Emperor has recently shown to the world to what excellent use, in the shape of territorial aggrandizement, the assassination of a few missionaries may be pit; and although Messrs. Bailly-Forfillere and Pauly were not missionaries, their deaths may be turned to an equally good account, for, both with the Chinese Empire and the Republic of Liberia, the possibilities of a successful resistance to preposterous demands for compensation are not perceptible.
I do not know whether the French Government has demanded compensation from the Republic. But the designs of France on Liberia have become so palpable during the last few years that it would be displaying a crass stupidity not to take very serious notice of this incident in light of the consequences to which it may give arise.
As most people know, Liberia is an indpendent Negro Republic which owers its inception to the philanthropic insitincts to the people of the United States, following in the wake of our own somewhat similar efforts in Sierra Leone. A colony of freed American negroes was gradually formed at Monrovia and various other points on the Grain Coast, and in 1847 the colonists were endowed with the consitution of the United States. Ever since, the Liberian Republic has eked out a somewhat miserable exsistence, falling every year deeper into debt, and conclusively providing in a thousand ways that the American negro lacks the elementary principles of self-government, being deficient in the very essentialties of constructive administration. certain foreign powers
2
